author: Michael Muncaster
title: Calls for Tyneside Tory to 'consider position' after sharing Yorkshire Ripper tweet
text:
News Calls for Tyneside Tory to 'consider position' after sharing Yorkshire Ripper tweet Alison Austin, Conservative councillor for Monkseaton North, retweeted a post claiming Peter Sutcliffe was a 'marvellous' lorry driver Share North Tyneside Tory councillor Alison Austin has been criticised after retweeting a joke about Peter Sutcliffe, the Yorkshire Ripper Share Get   
A Tory councillor defender her actions after sharing a social media post that compared Yorkshire Ripper Peter Sutcliffe to a “marvellous lorry driver”. 
Alison Austin, Conservative councillor for North Tyneside Council’s Monkseaton North ward , has been criticised by a Newcastle rape charity and an opposition councillor for sharing the post. 
The controversial message followed a tweet from former England and Tottenham footballer Gary Lineker arguing former Prime Minister Tony Blair was a “marvellous orator and speaks much sense on Brexit”, despite the Iraq war “staining” his reputation. 
A Twitter account named “Wes” replied saying: “Whatever you feel about Peter Sutcliffe and his rapey murders, he was a marvellous long distance lorry driver.” 
The response was then retweeted by Coun Austin. 
However, Coun Austin has issued a staunch defence claiming she was sharing a “pertinent point” about Tony Blair. The retweet by North Tyneside Tory councillor Alison Austin (Photo: NEC) 
Martin Rankin, Labour councillor for the Collingwood ward, said endorsing the post was a “shocking error of judgement” by Coun Austin. 
He said: “She seems to find merit in equating the actions of a serial killer with that of a former UK Prime Minister and in doing so she makes light of Peter Sutcliffe’s terrible crimes. 
“She should apologise immediately and consider her position.” Read More Yorkshire Ripper and Soham killer Ian Huntley in 'behind bars bust-up' at HMP Frankland 
The charity Rape Crisis Tyneside and Northumberland also condemned the tweet. 
A charity spokesman said: “Whenever we hear stories of this nature, our first thought is ‘what impact will this have on women who have experienced sexual violence?’ 
“In her tweet, Alison Austin appears to have been endorsing a sarcastic political comment. Humour is easily misinterpreted and we do not think it is helpful for women who have experienced sexual violence to see humour used in this way.” 
However, Coun Austin defended her actions and said she did not mean to cause any offence. 
She said: “I was not saying anything good about Peter Sutcliffe, saying that about him would be ridiculous. 
“It was not an endorsement and the guy was making a pertinent point [about Mr Blair]. I do not see anything wrong with the tweet.” Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
